Executive Summary

Goal. Analyze how driveline and transmission relate to city MPG, and compare statistical tests via simulation.
Methods. One-way ANOVA; blocked linear model + permutation logic; Kruskal–Wallis p-value comparison (asymptotic vs Monte Carlo); 10k-rep power study for Welch F vs pairwise Welch + Holm under sparse alternatives.
Key Findings.

FWD cars have higher city MPG than RWD/AWD (ANOVA, p ≪ 0.001).

Controlling for transmission, FWD ≈ +6 MPG vs RWD; Manual ≈ +3 MPG vs Automatic (both p ≪ 0.001).

KW: asymptotic ≈ Monte Carlo at n≈10 for type-I error and power.

Pairwise Welch + Holm > Welch F for power when only one group mean shifts; both control type-I error.
